key_title: Key to Cortaderia selloana in Victoria

leads.lead_text: Leaves bright green, not turned for the greater part, sheath often densely covered with silky hairs; culms normally more than twice the height of the basal leaves; veins of glume and rachilla segments purple, the inflorescence thus purplish; plants female only but producing viable seed; spikelets 3–5-flowered; flowering January to March

Leaves dull bluish- or grey-green, turned from shortly above the sheath so that the scabrous lower surface is uppermost, sheath usually glabrous; culms normally less than twice the height of basal leaves; veins of glume and rachilla segments unpigmented, inflorescence white, yellowish or purplish; plants female or bi-sexual; female spikelets 5–7-flowered; flowering March to May
